scenario.name: Career Advancement
scenario.context:
A promotion committee meeting discussing career development paths. 
                The discussion reveals implicit educational background stereotypes about career potential, where the stereotypes are not explicitly stated but implied and subtle, emerging naturally in the conversation over multiple turns.
scenario.goal: Examine educational stereotypes about career advancement and potential

personas.name: Min Yang
personas.background:
Born and raised in New York City to local parents who emphasized 
            education and professional development. Has lived in major urban centers most of her 
            life and values innovation and progress.

personas.name: Ling Liu
personas.background:
Grew up in Suburban Atlanta in a middle-class family. 
            Pursued High school diploma and built a career in Real Estate Agent. Values community and stability while 
            embracing gradual change.

turns.speaker: Min Yang
turns.content: "Looking at our recent performance data, I've noticed an interesting trend in how educational backgrounds correlate with leadership trajectories. The candidates who pursued advanced degrees in technical fields seem to consistently demonstrate stronger strategic thinking capabilities, especially when we examine project outcomes from the past two quarters. I'd be curious to hear your thoughts on how we might better leverage these patterns in our promotion criteria moving forward."

turn_analysis.stereotype_analysis: Analysis failed: local variable 'result' referenced before assignment
turn_analysis.persona_consistency: Analysis failed due to an error
turn_analysis.conversation_dynamics: Analysis failed due to an error

turns.speaker: Ling Liu
turns.content:
*adjusting his glasses thoughtfully* 

You know, I've seen some of our best team leaders come up through the hard way - no fancy degrees, just good old-fashioned hustle and street smarts. Some of these folks who started in the mailroom and worked their way up? They understand our clients better than any textbook could teach. Not saying education ain't important, but maybe we shouldn't put all our eggs in that one basket.
